Our findings here are subject to several important limitations and sources of uncertainty. First, given the high-resolution and computationally intensive methodology, our simulations are limited to a single climate-chemistry model. However, our finding that future climate change is likely to exacerbate China’s air pollution is broadly consistent with numerous previous studies ( 8
– 11, 25, 26, 28, 29) that used independent models and methods. In particular, several studies have indicated that weather conditions conducive to extreme haze will likely occur at a higher frequency in China under climate change as a result of large-scale circulation changes caused by the Arctic sea ice decline and the weakening of the East Asian winter monsoon ( 7 – 9). Yet, the original air stagnation index adopted by Cai et al. ( 8) and Horton et al. ( 14) does not capture the wintertime frequent haze events in China ( 30). By adopting a new air stagnation index ( Methods), we find that stagnation can identify a large fraction of severe haze events in China (
SI Appendix, Fig. S5 ). The increased frequency of stagnation events is consistent with the more frequent weather conditions conducive to extreme haze as reported by previous studies ( 7 – 9). Previous studies reveal 3 potential pathways linking midlatitude weather extremes to Arctic amplification, including changes in storm tracks, the jet stream, and planetary waves ( 9, 31), although there is not yet consensus regarding the Arctic linkages ( 32). Several studies have suggested that amplified planetary waves favor weather extremes in midlatitudes ( 33 – 35).
